awd_titl_txt: ME-Green: Manufacturing for Environment by Generating Renewable Energy in Enterprise Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to model and design a grid-connected onsite generation system featuring intermittent renewable power to realize zero-carbon industrial operations. Three fundamental questions will be addressed that are confronted by the manufacturing industries: 1) is it economically variable to deploy wind, solar and other green power to achieve energy independency, 2) is it technically feasible to operate a net-zero carbon facility using intermittent power, and 3) can distributed energy resources (DER)actively participate in demand responses by forming a virtual power plant to provide two-way energy flow? To answer these questions, multi-criteria stochastic programming models will be developed to optimize the DER sizing, siting, and maintenance for minimizing energy cost with ensuring reliability, resilience and power quality. Primary DER units include wind turbine, solar photovoltaics, combined heat and power, electric vehicles, and battery banks.

The research hypothesis is that that virtually any manufacturing facility around the world could be powered with 100 percent onsite wind and solar power at an affordable cost. This hypothesis will be tested in various locations around the world with diverse climatic conditions. Research activities include analytics, system modeling and optimization, and simulation to address the operational challenges pertaining to power intermittency, voltage stability, demand response, production-inventory schedule, grid resilience, and transportation electrification. This research makes an attempt to seek a zero-carbon energy solution for enterprise systems through the integration of intermittent renewable power. Though onsite generation and microgrids have been adopted by industries, an in-depth study on return-on-investment, loss-of-load risks, and interaction with utility grid is still rare in the literature. Methodologically, a two-stage optimization algorithm will be employed. In stage 1, the sizing and siting of DER units will be optimized. In stage 2, the maintenance policy to minimize the equipment lifecycle cost will be established. A two-stage decision process is able to eliminate inferior solutions in the initial search. In modeling, a probabilistic measure to ensure grid resilience by minimizing the DER and microgrid recovery time against natural disasters or extreme events will be employed. This research is targeted to assist the U.S. manufacturing industry in gaining unprecedented competitive advantages by transforming from power-intensive, carbon producers to environmentally-benign and energy-independent entities.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project is to design wind- and solar-based microgrid systems to realize cost-effective, carbon neutral manufacturing and supply chain operations. To address the generation intermittency, stochastic modeling and optimization strategies are proposed to determine the renewable portfolio, and the sizing and siting of microgrids to lower the levelized cost of energy. Research activities include data analytics, machine learning algorithms, systems modeling and optimization, and experimental design and simulation. Together they address the uncertainties pertaining to power supply, product demand, utility price, manufacturing capacity, and grid reliability. The proposed models are tested in various locations around the world covering diverse wind and weather profiles.

Intellectual Merit:

 (I) This research makes an early attempt to assess the cost and environmental benefits of installing and integrating renewable microgrids in manufacturing and supply chain facilities targeting carbon-neutral performance. The research findings show that a manufacturing plant could be powered with 100 percent onsite renewables at an affordable cost, provided that the capacity factor of wind and solar generation is above 0.25 and 0.3, respectively. In comparison with grid power, if the battery cost declines to $0.1M/MWh, this technology becomes cost competitive in hedging against renewable intermittency. (II) We propose two-stage stochastic, multi-stage stochastic, and chance constrained models to cope with operation uncertainties, such as product demand, labor and machine capacity, and power intermittency. The applicability and efficacy of the models are tested in 15 different cities (ten are in the U.S.) featuring 11-year, hourly meteorological data from 2005 to 2016. (III) Conceptually, this project represents a first-of-its-kind in synthesizing commodity and energy markets to achieve low-carbon supply chain operations in a nexus of climate, energy, transportation, and manufacturing. (IV) The study further investigates a multi-criteria, multi-year microgrid expansion model to achieve the distribution grid resilience under extreme weather. An improved direct zigzag algorithm is developed to search for the Pareto solution  frontier that is much wider than using evolutionary algorithms.

Broader Impacts:

(I) This project assists the U.S. manufacturing industry in transitioning from fossil fuel-based entities towards eco-friendly energy prosumers, hence maintaining the competitive edge in the global market. The research findings are applicable to a wide range of industry sectors, including oil refinery, semiconductor, electric transport and logistics, and commercial buildings. (II) The research findings have been disseminated broadly through a variety of channels. Particularly, the results are disseminated via 10 journal papers (6 published, and 4 under review), 4 peer-reviewed conference papers (3 published, and 1 accepted), and over 15 conference or poster presentations in large international conferences. The project developed and released a 90-page online course module to IEEE Robotics & Automation Society that sponsors a consortium formed by Texas State University and other five institutions from the USA, UK, and Italy. The project also results in 7 master theses and 1 PhD dissertation. In addition, the project develops joint research collaborations with four U.S. institutions. (III) A total of 13 Texas State University students directly participated in the project, including 4 undergraduate students, 7 master students, and 2 PhD student. Among them, 3 master students have graduated and are pursing PhD studies in three U.S. institutions. (IV). The project also provided excellent opportunities to enhance the engineering curriculum. The research findings have been embedded into course projects and lectures of three BS engineering and three MS/PhD courses, benefiting over 200 students at Texas State University. In fall 2020, the project also was advocated in a virtual recruiting event participated by over 30 sophomore students from Alamo Community College, TX. Co-sponsored by ME-GREEN, in 2018 two professors of Rutgers and Auburn University were invited to offer research seminars to students of Ingram School of Engineering, with a total of 60 participants. (V) Since 2018, the NSF ME-GREEN project motivated the Gulf Coast Power Association to increase their scholarship amount by $2,500 per year to the Ingram School of Engineering, benefiting multiple programs, including Industrial, Manufacturing, Electrical, Computer and Civil Engineering at Texas State University.

 

Acknowledgement:

 We would like to express our sincere appreciation to the NSF CBET program for the generous funding. We are also indebted to the staff of Texas State University for the strong support and assistance of project operations.
